intro: Buphthalmum salicifolium subsp. salicifolium, commonly known as the willow-leaf sunflower, is a flowering plant native to southern Africa. It is characterized by its lanceolate, willow-like leaves and large, showy yellow flowers that bloom in late summer. The plant typically grows in sandy or gravelly soils and is often found in coastal or inland regions. It is a member of the Asteraceae family, which includes daisies and sunflowers, and is known for its ability to thrive in arid conditions. The subspecies salicifolium is distinguished by its specific leaf morphology and floral structure compared to other subspecies of Buphthalmum.
